messages.content: Write H(z)H(z)H(z) as a power series in z‚àí1z^{-1}z‚àí1: make this obsidian latex

To write \( H(z)H(z)H(z) \) as a power series in \( z^{-1} \) using LaTeX in Obsidian, you can use the following format:

```markdown
\[
H(z)H(z)H(z) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_n z^{-n}
\]
```

In this expression, \( a_n \) represents the coefficients of the power series expansion. If you have specific coefficients or a specific function for \( H(z) \), you can replace the general form with the actual series expansion.

For causal LTI systems you usually have

. give tihs

For a causal Linear Time-Invariant (LTI) system, the transfer function \( H(z) \) can be expressed as a power series in \( z^{-1} \). In LaTeX for Obsidian, you can write it as follows:

```markdown
\[
H(z) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} h[n] z^{-n}
\]
```

Here, \( h[n] \) represents the impulse response of the system, and the series is summed over \( n \) from 0 to infinity, indicating that the system is causal.

i ment like this 
$$
H(z) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} h[n] z^{-n}
$$

Certainly! If you want to express \( H(z) \) as a bilateral (two-sided) Z-transform, which includes both positive and negative powers of \( z^{-1} \), you can write it in LaTeX for Obsidian like this:

```markdown
$$
H(z) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} h[n] z^{-n}
$$
```

This representation includes all possible values of \( n \), allowing for both causal and non-causal components in the system's impulse response \( h[n] \).

what is impulse response is it (h(n)) or H(z) and why ? 
what is its formula?

Short answer: the impulse response is the time-domain sequence h[n] (or h(t) in continuous time). H(z) is its Z-transform ‚Äî the transfer function (frequency-/complex-domain representation). H(z) and h[n] are two representations of the same LTI system.

Key points and formulas (use in Obsidian LaTeX):

- Definition of the unit impulse (discrete):
$$
\delta[n]=\begin{cases}1,&n=0,\\0,&n\ne0.\end{cases}
$$

- Impulse response: the output of the system when the input is the unit impulse:
$$
h[n]=\text{output when } x[n]=\delta[n].
$$

- Z-transform (transfer function) of the impulse response:
$$
H(z)=\mathcal{Z}\{h[n]\}=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} h[n]\,z^{-n}.
$$

- Input‚Äìoutput relation (convolution in time, multiplication in z‚Äëdomain):
$$
y[n]=(h*x)[n]=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} h[k]\,x[n-k],
\qquad
Y(z)=H(z)\,X(z).
$$

- Inverse Z‚Äëtransform (to recover h[n] from H(z)):
$$
h[n]=\frac{1}{2\pi j}\oint_C H(z)\,z^{\,n-1}\,dz,
$$
or by expanding H(z) as a power series in \(z^{-1}\):
$$
H(z)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} h[n]\,z^{-n}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad h[n]=\text{coefficient of }z^{-n}.
$$

- Useful properties:
  - Causality ‚áî \(h[n]=0\) for \(n<0\).
  - BIBO stability (discrete) ‚áî \(\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty |h[n]|<\infty\).
  - Frequency response: \(H(e^{j\omega})=\sum_n h[n] e^{-j\omega n}\) (evaluate \(H(z)\) on the unit circle if ROC includes it).

So: h[n] is the impulse response (time-domain). H(z) is its Z-transform (complex-/frequency-domain representation).

Stopband: ‚à£H(ejœâ)‚à£‚â§0.2,‚ÄÖ‚Ääœâs=3œÄ/4‚â§œâ‚â§œÄ|H(e^{j\omega})|\le 0.2,\; \omega_s = 3\pi/4 \le \omega \le \pi‚à£H(ejœâ)‚à£‚â§0.2,œâs‚Äã=3œÄ/4‚â§œâ‚â§œÄ.

(Interpretation note: the PDF text is slightly garbled around œâp\omega_pœâp‚Äã. I took the standard exam-style interpretation and used œâp=œÄ/2\omega_p=\pi/2œâp‚Äã=œÄ/2 which is a common choice; if your problem intended a different œâp\omega_pœâp‚Äã, the numeric result changes only in the prewarp step ‚Äî the procedure stays identical.)
copilot format this note 
Design a digital Butterworth IIR filter that meets the above specifications using the bilinear transform method. Provide the following:
The order N of the filter.

messages.content:
[[M3]]

Design (bilinear transform / Butterworth) ‚Äî find filter order N
$$
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Given (from [[M3]]):}\quad 0.9 \le |H(e^{j\omega})|\le 1,\; 0\le\omega\le\omega_p,\qquad |H(e^{j\omega})|\le 0.2,\; \omega_s=\tfrac{3\pi}{4}\le\omega\le\pi,\\
&\text{sampling period: }T=1,\qquad\text{interpretation: }\omega_p=\tfrac{\pi}{2}.
\end{aligned}
$$

1) Convert magnitude specs to dB
$$
A_p=-20\log_{10}(0.9)\approx 0.915\ \text{dB},\qquad
A_s=-20\log_{10}(0.2)\approx 13.979\ \text{dB}.
$$

2) Prewarp digital edge frequencies (bilinear, \(T=1\))
$$
\Omega_p=\tan\!\left(\frac{\omega_p}{2}\right)=\tan\!\left(\frac{\pi/2}{2}\right)=\tan\!\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)=1,
$$
$$
\Omega_s=\tan\!\left(\frac{\omega_s}{2}\right)=\tan\!\left(\frac{3\pi/8}\right)=1+\sqrt{2}\approx 2.41421356.
$$

3) Butterworth order formula
$$
N = \left\lceil \frac{\ln\!\left(\dfrac{10^{0.1A_s}-1}{\,10^{0.1A_p}-1\,}\right)}{2\ln\!\left(\dfrac{\Omega_s}{\Omega_p}\right)} \right\rceil.
$$

Insert numbers:
$$
10^{0.1A_p}-1 \approx 10^{0.091515}-1 \approx 0.2342,\qquad
10^{0.1A_s}-1 \approx 10^{1.3979}-1 \approx 24.
$$
$$
\frac{10^{0.1A_s}-1}{10^{0.1A_p}-1}\approx \frac{24}{0.2342}\approx 102.45,\qquad
2\ln\!\left(\frac{\Omega_s}{\Omega_p}\right)=2\ln(2.4142)\approx 1.7627.
$$
$$
N=\left\lceil\frac{\ln(102.45)}{1.7627}\right\rceil=\left\lceil\frac{4.629}{1.7627}\right\rceil=\lceil 2.626\rceil=3.
$$

Answer:
$$
\boxed{N=3}
$$

(If you want, I can continue and compute the analog prototype cutoff \(\Omega_c\), the analog poles, and then apply the bilinear transform to get the final digital IIR coefficients.)
